sen.j: アヂスキタカヒコネ（アヂシキタカヒコネとも）は、日本神話に登場する神 (神道)。
sen.e: Ajisukitakahikone or Ajishikitakahikone is a Shinto deity who appears in the Japanese Mythology.
Ajisukitakahikone or Ajishikitakahikone is a Shinto deity who appears in Japanese Mythology.
Ajisukitakahikone or Ajishikitakahikone is a Shinto deity who appears in Japanese Mythology.

sen.j: 古事記では阿遅鉏高日子根神、阿遅志貴高日子根神、阿治志貴高日子根神と表記する。
sen.e: In the Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters), it is written in Japanese kanji as "阿遅鉏高日子根神," "阿遅志貴高日子根神," or "阿治志貴高日子根神."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In the Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters), it is written in Japanese kanji as "阿遅鉏高日子根神," "阿遅志貴高日子根神," or "阿治志貴高日子根神."
In the Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters), it is written in Japanese kanji as "阿遅鉏高日子根神," "阿遅志貴高日子根神," or "阿治志貴高日子根神."

sen.j: 出雲国風土記では阿遅須枳高日子と表記する。
sen.e: In the Izumo fudoki (topography of Izumo Province), it is written as "阿遅須枳高日子."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In the Izumo fudoki (topography of Izumo Province), it is written as "阿遅須枳高日子."
In the Izumo fudoki (topography of Izumo Province), it is written as "阿遅須枳高日子."

sen.j: また、阿遅鋤高日子根神、味耜高彦根命とも表記される。
sen.e: It is also written as "阿遅鋤高日子根神," or "味耜高彦根命."
It is also written as "阿遅鋤高日子根神," or "味耜高彦根命."
It is also written as "阿遅鋤高日子根神," or "味耜高彦根命."

sen.j: 別名 迦毛大御神（かものおおみかみ）。
sen.e: His another name is "Kamono Omikami."
His other name is "Kamono Omikami."
His other name is "Kamono Omikami."

sen.j: 神話での記述
sen.e: Descriptions in the Japanese Mythology
Descriptions in Japanese Mythology
Descriptions in Japanese mythology
sen.cmt: 文頭以外の語頭を小文字に

sen.j: 大国主と宗像三女神のタキリビメの間の子。
sen.e: He was born between Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region) and Takiri-bime, one of the Munakata Sanjojin (three goddesses enshrined in the Munakata-taisha Shirine).

He was born between Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region) and Takiri-bime, one of the Munakata Sanjojin (three goddesses enshrined in the Munakata-taisha Shirine).

He was born between Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region) and Takiri-bime, one of the Munakata Sanjojin (three goddesses enshrined in the Munakata-taisha Shirine).

sen.j: 同母の妹にタカヒメ（シタテルヒメ）がいる。
sen.e: Taka-hime (Shitateru-hime) is his half sister by the same mother.
Taka-hime (Shitateru-hime) is his half sister by the same mother.
Taka-hime (Shitateru-hime) is his half sister by the same mother.

sen.j: 古事記では、葦原中国平定において登場する。
sen.e: In the Kojiki, he appears in Ashihara no Nakatsukuni heitei (the conquest of the world between Heaven and Hell - the human world).
In the Kojiki, he appears in Ashihara no Nakatsukuni heitei (the conquest of the world between Heaven and Hell - the human world).
In the Kojiki, he appears in Ashihara no Nakatsukuni heitei (the conquest of the world between Heaven and Hell - the human world).

sen.j: シタテルヒメの夫で、高天原に復命しなかったために死んでしまったアメノワカヒコの葬儀を訪れた。
sen.e: He attended the funeral of Amenowakahiko, Shitateru-hime's husband, who died because he did not report on his mission to Takamanohara (Heaven).
He attended the funeral of Amenowakahiko, Shitateru-hime's husband, who died because he did not report on his mission to Takamanohara (Heaven).
He attended the funeral of Amenowakahiko, Shitateru-hime's husband, who died because he did not report on his mission to Takamanohara (Heaven).

sen.j: しかし、アヂスキタカヒコネはアメノワカヒコとそっくりであったため、アメノワカヒコの父のアマツクニタマが、アメノワカヒコが生きていたものと勘違いして抱きついてきた。
sen.e: However, Ajisukitakahikone so closely resembled Amenowakahiko that Amatsukunitama, Amenowakahiko's father, misunderstood that his son was still alive, and hugged him.
However, Ajisukitakahikone so closely resembled Amenowakahiko that Amatsukunitama, Amenowakahiko's father, misunderstood that his son was still alive, and hugged him.
However, Ajisukitakahikone so closely resembled Amenowakahiko that Amatsukunitama, Amenowakahiko's father, misunderstood that his son was still alive, and hugged him.

sen.j: アヂスキタカヒコネは穢わしい死人と一緒にするなと怒り、剣を抜いて喪屋を切り倒し、蹴り飛ばしてしまった。
sen.e: As Ajisukitakahikone got angry for being mixed up with an impure dead person, he cut down the mortuary house with a sword and kicked it off.
As Ajisukitakahikone got angry for being mixed up with an impure dead person, he cut down the mortuary house with a sword and kicked it off.
As Ajisukitakahikone got angry for being confused with a dead person, he cut down the funeral house with a sword and destroyed it.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: シタテルヒメはアヂスキタカヒコネの名を明かす歌を詠んだ。
sen.e: Shitateru-hime composed a tanka (a 31-syllable Japanese poem) to disclose the identity of Ajisukitakahikone.
Shitateru-hime composed a tanka (a 31-syllable Japanese poem) to disclose the identity of Ajisukitakahikone.
Shitateru-hime composed a tanka (a 31-syllable Japanese poem) to disclose the identity of Ajisukitakahikone.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 出雲国風土記によれば、幼い時、その泣き叫ぶ声が非常に大きかったので、静かになるまで船に乗せて八十島（日本）を巡ったり、高屋を作って梯子をかけそれを上り下りさせたりした。
sen.e: According to the Izumo fudoki, in early childhood, his crying and screaming were so loud that he was forced to get into a boat to sail the Yasoshima (many islalnds, Japan) until he calmed down, or to go up and down the ladder set up against the high tower.

According to the Izumo fudoki, in early childhood, his crying and screaming were so loud that he was forced to get into a boat to sail to the Yasoshima (many islalnds, Japan) until he calmed down, or go up and down a ladder set up against a high tower.

According to the Izumo fudoki (the topography of Izumo Province), in early childhood, his crying and screaming were so loud that he was forced to get into a boat to sail to the Yasoshima islands until he calmed down, or repeatedly climb up and down a ladder set up against a high tower.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。用語補足しました。

sen.j: 天御梶日女（あめのみかじひめ）との間に雨の神である多伎都比古（たきつひこ）をもうけたとしている。
sen.e: With Ame no mikaji-hime, he had a child named Takitsuhiko, the god of rain.
He had a child named Takitsuhiko with Ame no mikaji-hime, the god of rain.
He had a child named Takitsuhiko with Ame no mikaji-hime, the god of rain.

sen.j: 解説
sen.e: Commentary
Commentary
Commentary

sen.j: 神名の「スキ（シキ）」は鋤のことで、鋤を神格化した農耕神である。
sen.e: "Suki or Shiki" used in this god's name means spade; the deification of spade might lead him to become the god of agriculture.
"Suki or Shiki" used in this god's name means spade; the deification of spade might lead him to become the god of agriculture.
Suki or Shiki' used in this god's name means spade; the deification of spade might lead him to become the god of agriculture.

sen.j: 『古事記伝』では「アヂ」は「可美（うまし）」と同義語であり、「シキ」はを磯城で石畳のことであるとしている。
sen.e: According to "Kojikiden (Commentaries on the Kojiki)," "Aji" used in his name is a synonym for "Umashi (splended)," and "Shiki"written as 磯城 means stone pavement.
According to "Kojikiden (Commentaries on the Kojiki)," "Aji" used in his name is a synonym for "Umashi (splended)," and "Shiki"written as 磯城 means stone pavement.
According to "Kojikiden (Commentaries on the Kojiki)," 'Aji' used in his name is a synonym for 'Umashi (splendid),' and 'Shiki' written as 磯城 means stone pavement.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせ"を'にスペル

sen.j: 他に、「シキ」は大和の磯城（しき）のことであるとする説もある。
sen.e: There is another opinion that "Shiki" means Shiki in Yamato Province.
There is another opinion that "Shiki" means Shiki in Yamato Province.
There is another opinion that 'Shiki' means Shiki in Yamato Province.

sen.j: アメノワカヒコとそっくりであったとの記述から、元々アメノワカヒコと同一の神で、穀物が秋に枯れて春に再生する、または太陽が冬に力が弱まり春に復活する様子を表したものであるとする説もある。
sen.e: There is also a theory regarding the origin of Ajisukitakahikone; he and Amenowakahiko are originally defined as the same god from a description of their resemblance; he symbolizes that cereals which withered in autumun regrow in spring, or that the sun whose power deteriorated in winter revives in spring.

There is also a theory regarding the origin of Ajisukitakahikone; he and Amenowakahiko are originally defined as the same god from a description of their resemblance; he symbolizes that cereals that wither in autumun regrow in spring, or that the sun whose power deteriorated in winter revives in spring.

There is also a theory regarding the origin of Ajisukitakahikone in which he and Amenowakahiko were originally defined as the same god from a description of their resemblance; and he symbolizes grains which wither in autumn and regrow in spring, or the sun which becomes lower in Winter and higher in Spring.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 古事記における天地を行き来する姿や激情ぶり、出雲国風土記における泣き叫ぶ声の大きさや梯子を上り下りする姿は、雷を表したものである。
sen.e: The Kojiki describes the way he comes and goes between heaven and earth, and how much he gets infuriated; the Izumo fudoki also describes how loudly he cries and screams, and the way he goes up and down the ladder; these descriptions imply thunder.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The Kojiki describes the way he comes and goes between heaven and earth, and how much he gets infuriated; the Izumo fudoki also describes how loudly he cries and screams, and the way he goes up and down the ladder; these descriptions imply thunder.

The Kojiki describes the way he comes and goes between heaven and earth, and how much he gets infuriated; the Izumo fudoki also describes how loudly he cries and screams, and the way he goes up and down the ladder; these descriptions imply thunder.

sen.j: アジスキタカヒコネは鋤と雷の霊力を合わせた神である。
sen.e: Ajisukitakahikone is the god combining miraculous power of spade and thunder.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Ajisukitakahikone is the god combining miraculous power of spade and thunder.
Ajisukitakahikone is the god combining miraculous power of spade and thunder.

sen.j: 別名は賀茂社の神の意味である。
sen.e: His another name means the god of the Kamo-sha Shrine.
His other name means the god of Kamo-sha Shrine.
His other name means the god of Kamo-sha Shrine.

sen.j: すなわちこの神は大和国葛城の賀茂社の鴨氏が祭っていた大和の神である。
sen.e: Accordingly, he is the god of Yamato which was worshiped by the Kamo clan, a family of the Kamo-sha Shrine in Katsuragi, Yamato Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Accordingly, he is the god of Yamato which was worshiped by the Kamo clan, a family of the Kamo-sha Shrine in Katsuragi, Yamato Province.
Accordingly, he is the god of Yamato which was worshiped by the Kamo clan, a family of the Kamo-sha Shrine in Katsuragi, Yamato Province.

sen.j: しかしながら、鴨氏は出雲から大和に移住したとする説もある。
sen.e: However, there is an opinion that the Kamo clan moved from the Izumo Province to the Yamato Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, there is an opinion that the Kamo clan moved from Izumo Province to Yamato Province.
However, there is an opinion that the Kamo clan moved from Izumo Province to Yamato Province.

sen.j: 古事記で最初から「大御神」と呼ばれているのは、天照大御神と迦毛大御神だけである。
sen.e: Amaterasu Omikami and Kamono Omikami are the only examples that are called "Omikami (Great God) in the Kojiki from the beginning.
Amaterasu Omikami and Kamono Omikami are the only examples that are called "Omikami" (Great God) in the Kojiki from the beginning.
Amaterasu Omikami and Kamono Omikami are the only examples of deities which are called 'Omikami' (Great God) from the beginning of the Kojiki.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。前出補足をのぞきました。

sen.j: 信仰
sen.e: Religion
Religion
Religion

sen.j: 農業の神、雷の神、不動産業の神として信仰されており、高鴨神社（奈良県御所市）、都々古別神社（福島県東白川郡棚倉町）などに祀られている。
sen.e: Ajisukitakahikone is worshiped as the god of agriculture, thunder, or real estate business, and enshrined in the Takakamo-jinja Shrine (Gose City, Nara Prefecture) and Tsutsukowake-jinja Shrine (Tanagura-machi, Higashishirakawa-gun, Fukushima Prefecture).

Ajisukitakahikone is worshiped as the god of agriculture, thunder, or real estate business, and is enshrined in the Takakamo-jinja Shrine (Gose City, Nara Prefecture) and Tsutsukowake-jinja Shrine (Tanagura-machi, Higashishirakawa-gun, Fukushima Prefecture).

Ajisukitakahikone is worshiped as the god of agriculture, thunder, or real estate business, and is enshrined in the Takakamo-jinja Shrine (Gose City, Nara Prefecture) and Tsutsukowake-jinja Shrine (Tanagura-machi, Higashishirakawa-gun, Fukushima Prefecture).
